ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Ir frastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is entered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK ("ADB"), headquartered at 6 ADB Avenue, Mandaluyong 11 1550, Metro Manila, Philippii es; (2) EUROPEAN BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("EBRD"), headqu -t -ed at One Exchange Square, London EC2A 2JN, United Kingdom; (3) EUROPEAN INVESTMENT BANK ("EIB"), headquartered at 98-100, boulevard Konrad Adenauer, L-2950 Luxembourg; (4) ISLAMIC DEVELOPMENT flANK ("IsDB"), headquartered at Qasr Khuzam Street 5925, ld Jah, Saudi Arabia 21432; and (5) THE WORLD BANK GROU ', comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND [,EVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPI I i T ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), hea iquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, U , ne INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylva i: Avenue, NW, Washington, CC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D: 2r 433, USA (the "World Bank Groip") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties" or the "MDBs"). Preamble (A) There is broad internation I recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Intei i1: )nal Organizations (1Os), the G7', and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir g ii the infrastructure of Emerging larkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to Ex and access to basic services an J raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic .1 wth targets. (B) Meeting this need present; a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on ex ting sources of infrastructure fine nce-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coc,( ir ited effort is needed to mobilize r rivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of rob ist pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an It s is understood to be the greates t barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investrr ei (D) Governments, development 'inance institutions, donors, and private investors share an ir:E r: st in developing the market for pivate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand t: 3, in the numbers of structurally s und and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual err anc nce of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range c : late investors that actively participate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals wil :l iefit from collective action betwE en this range of entities-to leverage resources and know e:1; e to find solutions to complex nfrastructure financing challenges that no single instituticin : iuld achieve alone. (E) The Parties have, since their inception, and in accordance with their respective ins 1.J )nal mandates, helped EMDE cl ent countries meet their infrastructure needs, both collecti' e ly and individually. As such, the Pa ties have operational and technical knowledge in preparing iic i Jve, sustainable infrastructure projects, creating an enabling environment for infra: t'L ture investment, and leveraging both public and private sector resources to implement these :i (D icts. This support is provided thr)ugh an extensive range of existing and proposed initiative , f. ids, advisory services, and other forms of legal, institutional, and financial support (see Anne: It is 1
ï»¿Execution Version recognized that an enhance i level of collaboration across these facilities and support a:1 ies, particularly in the context oi complex projects with the potential to leverage substantia pr ate capital, could be of benefit to Nards meeting their mutual goals. (F) In support of these goals, thE Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure FE ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leveral ii(: the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruct ne vith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prep a Ion, structuring, and risk mitigati n for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, he GIF aims to complement existini and proposed services and initiatives currently supportec : the Parties and other prospectivE GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prep, ri ,ell- structured, infrastructure prcjects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces .i (; the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro F,, tive private sector financiers into roject structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater I e age of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particLlar I:> rge and complex projects with th,. potential to attract significant private capital. (G) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure IE ility Partnership Program, togethor with other partners. Accordingly, the Parties have com to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Faciliy Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended o be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set c.j il Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fo indational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their colla :cr. tion, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties anc wi,il 1 other potential partners until he GIF is formally established. The final version of these objicti es and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend tc work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to fL rther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing l: IF, with a view to formally establ shing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the forec oing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue t:> collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the roles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each catego y b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies 3pplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proj ct selection criteria anc coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, inclut in i sharing best practicE and experience with regard to project preparation, through tl E I;e of knowledge platfor ns for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali.:ing the design of the GIF, the MDBs will be invited to partic Pa! ! as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF design is finalized, additional collaborative efi:)tv are required to develop the operational details for the GIF, at all times complementing e) ting 2
ï»¿Execution Version efforts and facilities and bL ilding upon the shared knowledge and experience of the P1 :i s in this area. This includes de:ermining the level of coordination between the Parties anc :i ject origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration A rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitmen I i he Parties to enter into or provice support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisi )ns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commc - understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose a v gal obligations or liabilities on ary Party. 3.2 This Collaboration A rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year fron h date thereof, unless superse Jed at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collaboi a H activities contemplated herei i will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wit i e: h other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppoi 1: regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arranlement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciati :ii I other modification of any of t ie privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of t1 - Parties under their constituent documents, international conventions and any applicable le ,s In witness whereof, each of the Par:ies has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be executi c ii two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party e ac the date first set forth above. 3

ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the 31F is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure p (jf :ts in emerging markets and de\ eloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparat :i provision of appropriate risk nitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commerciz I :1i institutional investor engagernent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pub ic-private partnerships and projects with potential for comme -rE viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastrL c: e financing solutions that no siigle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF 3ims to create a global platform to provide financial and coon i ui ion resources in collaboration wi h the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of tl-:3 v, de range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMD: infrastructure, with the input ind ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engageme ii c uld stretch from upstream suppo I on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risl, mitigation/credit enhancemef it. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurEd infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla3s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking lonc t: i assets in faster growing ecor omies, but which until now have been presented only lirrited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profilE s 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to o )erate according to the following core principles, to be finalizE c )on agreement among GIF partn,rs: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities tI : till draw together ccmparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing put lic goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thos infrastructure prcjects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sust Ainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to tes practice standards for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tE Zh cal and financial res >urces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mu :i a! )ral development ins itutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ar innovative and fl.xible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greatE leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that arE beyond the resources of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t I( development and implementotion of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p r ni rs are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 9
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF w i1 considered Func ing Partners. (ii) Technical Partrers-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-fund( c activities and/or )rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity supp :fl instruments. (iii) Advisory Partnors-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial andiDr institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovE reign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as w 1 3; other multilatera or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure prc.jects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparE:i optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, witt a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial arid/or institutional inve!;tment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmir g management and use of funds, and development of operational policies and procedures; ir hold the GIF Management U it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the factlity' objectives and principles, wit i advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compo i:i: i of the Governing Council will bE agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is prop :i.E to comprise representatives of :unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dir t. and Chief Financial Officer o the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facili Etc coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve as sounding board, providing gL idance and support for GIF Management, and in particular w I1 view to ensuring suitability oi projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admiiistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate i :Em established for this purpose (the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will f in:: n as a coordinating body as projects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo\ e toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in li i: Jal projects. 4.2 GIF activity impleme itation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partne institutions, coordinated by tl e GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governme is according to specific project equirements and the project origination processes. Compos :i:) of the implementation teams m iy vary according to the need of individual projects and gove rml !nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection ci iteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follo%i,i( principles: (i) Development Inipact-projects that support the development goals of the GI= partner institutioi is; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities a3. strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr jects that require multiple parties to come together to provid! structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a bl :. lo of financial instrum )nts; and 10
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial iE ility, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- L h as through Publi -Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's se vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastr icture investments that have global public good characteristi :5 uch as climate friendly-project 3 that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisiol I infrastructure services; and t *ade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnE:. i\ -y and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppcrt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, witl- Z ew to complementing the resour.,es and support already available from partner entities and o h:. funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following a< tw es, corresponding to major proje:t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; prciect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility sci s: ng; and legal, regulatory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati:)n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and P 1P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, anc design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financ n. packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- ncluding in particular the management of environmental and s al impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastr .ilt. -e projects in supporting sustair able, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supportec operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements *r external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards an :l er standards and policies, and < evelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for G 1: Technical Partners who are (xpected to function as implementing entities for GIF activitie, 11
